comment.author: 11914939@N06
comment._content: I  can tell you all about Jack. For some reason the photo is labeled wrong.The midget is my great uncle and his name is Jack Barnett.He's from Roxboro, NC and was 42 inches tall. He and his brother were with Barnum and Bailey for over 20 years.Herbert was 36 inches tall. I love collecting anything and everything about them.If anyone has photos my email is mag7girl@hotmail.com. I have many photos of them both and know lots more info about them.My name is Luanne

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: New York Times feature story about circus freaks, Sunday, April 6, 1913, mentions Jack Barnett: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9D04E... He was toastmaster at a birthday banquet of Barnum and Bailey freaks held at Healy's Restaurant in New York, April 5, 1914. New York Times story, April 6, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=950CE3DF143EE7...

comment.author: 11914939@N06
comment._content: Wystan? Do you know how I might access the Libaray of Congress to find my Daddy's Tobaccl Leaf articles he wrote for them? I know they had them at one time in a big bound book but the lady that found them never could figure how to copy them being bound. Its me Luanne Barnett my Daddy was Frank Barnett and wrote for that magazine in the late 40's articles called The Barnetts Corner using an old Tobacco Barn as the Barn in barnetts.

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: theconfederatekitten: A magazine titled The Tobacco Leaf (subtitle: devoted to the wholesale and retail cigar and tobacco interests of the world) is held in the General Collections here at the Library of Congress, which are accessed through the Main Reading Room. The catalog record is here. The contents are not available online, but if you submit an Ask A Librarian email question to the reference staff in the Main Reading Room, they may be able to assist you in tracking down the articles by your father, Frank Barnett. Submit your question here, and a librarian will respond to you. Best of luck with your research!
